awd_titl_txt: Precision Measurement of Atomic Dipole Matrix Elements Using Tune-Out Wavelength Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Although an atom is sometimes depicted with the electrons orbiting the nucleus like planets orbit the sun, in reality motion at the atomic scale is governed by the laws of quantum mechanics. These say that even though the electron is a point-like particle, it is impossible to say exactly where an electron is at any given time. Instead, the location of an electron is spread out around the nucleus. In order to understand an atom's properties it is necessary to know how all its electrons are spread out.  One useful set of properties that measure how electrons are distributed are the "dipole matrix elements" (numerical values that arise from particular mathematical constructs which help describe how the electron distributions change when the energy of the atom is changed). Even the dipole matrix elements cannot be measured directly, but they can be reliably inferred from several types of experiments. Recently, a new way to obtain dipole matrix elements more precisely has been demonstrated, called tune-out wavelength spectroscopy. For this project, tune-out wavelength measurements will be used to obtain improved values for several matrix elements of the rubidium atom.  One example of why these measurements are important relates to whether an atom has "handedness," like a right-handed or left-handed glove. Theories and measurements in nuclear physics indicate that the atomic nucleus has a handedness. The role of this handedness in nuclear physics is very important for understanding how matter was created in the early universe, and why the universe looks the way it does now. It can be studied in large particle accelerators, but doing so is difficult and expensive. In an atom, a slight amount of the handedness is transmitted from the nucleus to the electrons. Although the effect is small, the atomic handedness can be measured very precisely and this has been useful for improving nuclear physics theories. However, relating the atomic measurement to nuclear physics requires accurate dipole matrix elements. The improved values that will be provided by this project will be useful for this purpose, and in this way help improve our understanding of why the universe is as it is.

In tune-out wavelength spectroscopy, the atom is illuminated by a laser beam that is tuned far from any atomic resonances. In most cases, this causes the energy of the atom to change. The energy can either increase or decrease, depending on the wavelength of the light. At specific wavelengths, however, the energy change is exactly zero. The value of these wavelengths depends on the dipole matrix elements of the atom, and by measuring the wavelength accurately the ratios of various matrix elements can be determined with high precision. The method used in this project to determine the tune-out wavelength is atom interferometry. Here the overall wave function of the atom is split into two branches that separate in space. One branch passes through the laser, and any resulting energy change results in a phase shift of the wave function. When the two branches are later recombined, this phase shift can be detected. The tune-out wavelength is determined by adjusting the laser to make the phase shift zero. A particular focus of this project will be to observe how the tune-out wavelength depends on the polarization of the laser light. By combining polarization-dependent measurements at a few different tune-out wavelengths, it is possible to accurately extract several groups of small matrix elements that are otherwise very challenging to measure or calculate. These small matrix elements are nonetheless important, as they represent dominant uncertainties in measurements of atomic parity violation and other atomic properties like the dc electric polarizability.

por.por_cntn:
The modern physical picture of an atom consists of a set of electrons surrounding a compact nucleus. Rather than orbiting the nucleus like planets orbit the sun, the electrons in an atom occupy wave-like states call wave functions. There are a countably infinite number of possible wave functions, and each wave function can be occupied by at most one electron at a time. In principle, we can calculate the nature of these wave functions using the Schrodinger equation, but in practice when there are more than two or three electrons, the computation becomes intractable.  Instead the wave functions must be computed using approximate methods or characterized experimentally. The approximate calculations provide more information, but experiments are important to validate the approximations.

It is impossible to measure the quantum wave functions directly, but information about them can be extracted by exposing the atom to an electric field and measuring how the energy of the atom changes.  However, the accuracy of such measurements is limited by how well the electric field can be calibrated. More precise information can be obtained by applying an oscillating field and determining the oscillation frequency at which the energy shift of the atom is zero. This does not depend on the field strength, and oscillation frequencies can be measured very accurately. Frequencies where the energy shift is zero are called tune-out frequencies.

Tune-out frequencies have been measured before, but additional information can be obtained by exploring how a tune-out frequency depends on the direction of the applied electric field. Previous measurements effectively averaged over all possible directions of the field, generating what is called a scalar tune-out measurement. When the field has a definite direction, it is called a vector tune-out measurement.

A challenge of the vector measurement is that the direction of the field needs to be well characterized. In this work we developed a set of techniques that allowed the direction to be controlled with a precision equivalent to 0.005 degrees. We were then able to measure a vector tune-out frequency for rubidium atoms, with a precision of about 400 parts per billion. Our result agrees with a theoretical approximation within this uncertainty. The estimated uncertainty of the theory result itself is about 60 parts per billion. We expect it is possible to improve our measurement precision by another factor of ten, which would then provide a stringent test of the theoretical methods.

While it is intrinsically interesting to understand how the electrons in an atom behave, developing and testing high-precision methods to calculate the wave functions is also important for many applications. A notable example is atomic parity violation. Parity describes mirror-image symmetry, where if the laws of physics allow an event to occur, then they also allow the mirror image of that event to occur. It turns out that parity symmetry does not hold in nuclear physics, and the lack of symmetry may be related to big questions like why the universe contains more matter than anti-matter. The lack of parity symmetry has a measurable impact on how the electrons in an atom can transition between different states. However, in order to relate the measured transition rates to the parity-violating effects in the nucleus, it is necessary to know the electronic wave functions quite precisely. At the present time, our knowledge about parity violation is limited more by uncertainty in the wave functions than by the transition rate measurements, so improvements in the calculation methods would have immediate impact. By providing precise experimental benchmarks, we hope that the results obtained here will facilitate such improvements.
